pullRequest.body:
This adds `NumberTheory.DirichletCharacter.Bounds` containing proofs of `‖χ a‖ = 1` if `a` is a unit and `‖χ a‖ ≤ 1` in general, where `χ` is a Dirichlet character with values in a normed field.

There are also two API lemmas added elsewhere that are used in the proofs.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:

- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7010064037/job/19069774801)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7010064037/job/19069774506)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7010064037/job/19069774108)

Thanks!

bors d+

Thanks!

bors d+
I believe this lemma should work as is for `LinearOrderedSemiring` ; I think that is more general.
OK, true.

The lemma seems fine. Would it be better to make this a definition and lemma instead? Something to the effect of defining `m` for all `n` and then making a lemma which gives you the property `m` satifies, in this case `a ^ m = 1`. That way you can retrieve the value of `m` if needed.
I would like to have some input from others on this.

See [this Zulip thread](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/144837-PR-reviews/topic/.238449.20Bounds.20for.20Dirichlet.20character.20values/near/402866446). I have replaced this lemma by a finiteness instance (and adapted the proof that used it).
Sorry if I missed this - why not make `n` implicit?

Why make it implicit? In (the unlikely) case I want to use the instance explicitly, I will likely need it for some concrete `n`, in which case `finiteZModUnits n` is more convenient than `@finiteZModUnits n` or `finiteZModUnits (n := n)`. For type class resolution it shouldn't matter.
Alright, seems fine!
Could you please tell me where you use the `NormedField` hypothesis? I have a feeling this should work more generally (I can see that `norm_pow` uses `NormedDivisionRing`).
It is needed for `norm_pow`. Otherwise, there is only `norm_pow_le`, which goes in the wrong direction.

```suggestion
We consider Dirichlet characters `χ` with values in a normed field `F`.
```
OK, thanks!

Nitpick: the adjacent lemmas using the label `a` rather than `x`:
```suggestion
lemma pow_eq_one_iff_of_nonneg {a : R} (hx : 0 ≤ a)
```
OK.

```suggestion
instance instFiniteZModUnits : (n : ℕ) → Finite (ZMod n)ˣ
```
OK.

```suggestion
@[simp] lemma unit_norm_eq_one (a : (ZMod n)ˣ) : ‖χ a‖ = 1 := by
```
OK.
